subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: ... That would be great if it worked. Unfortunately, the compiler, even in a language like Eiffel, can only detect constraint violations at compile time in the
messageBody:
On Wednesday, April 2, 2003, at 02:46 PM, javainsel wrote:

> I wish I would be a expert to convince you of a better approach than
> JUnit provides (and TDD).
>
> But I try.
>
> I consider Design by Contract to be suitable to replace JUnit and TDD
> completely. It can provide many benefits and by the same time not
> having all the side effects that JUnit and TDD have. Examples are
> Eiffel and Java Modelling Language (JML).
>
> Why? How? I'll explain.
>
> Testing of the code (methods) can be done with precondition,
> invartiants and postconditions (the contracts). Thats how I
> understand Design by Contract. You write your method definition and
> then you write the contract for it. Then you implement your method.
>
> Now the great thing: When you compile your code the implementation
> can be checked whether it obeys the contract. If not, a compile error
> is thrown. That it! No JUnit test needed! Not TDD needed! Besides
> this, a contract serves as a documentation. And it can use invariants
> which JUnit will always lack of.

That would be great if it worked. Unfortunately, the compiler, even in
a language like Eiffel, can only detect constraint violations at
compile time in the simplest of cases. A design-by-contract language
just inserts run-time checks the rest of the time. The run-time checks
only work if all the code is actually executed. If a method is not run
in testing, the check will never have a chance to fail before it gets
in the hands of users. This leaves you with either trying to run the
application manually and try *everything* or find a way to automate the
test process. This in turn leads to something like JUnit.

An additional problem with design-by-contract is that general-purpose
postcondition checks are difficult to write. With a non-trivial method,
the postcondition code must often either be as complex as the method
itself (and therefore at least as likely to have errors) or must depend
on the same underlying code as the method (I see people cut and paste
often). Writing an external test-case is often much easier by
comparison. You can choose inputs for which the output is easy to
verify and control the environment using constructs like Mock-Objects.

Design-by-contract does not replace unit-testing. When combined with
design-by-contract, unit testing is much more effective. When the
application is constantly verifying its own state, failures tend to
occur much closer to the actual bug than otherwise. It is very possible
for a testcase without DBC to succeed but leave the code in an unstable
state. Since a unit test throws away its data after every run, this
will not be detected without either more complex unit tests or
design-by-contract assertions.

Design-by-contract assertions also allow one to check internal state
that one does not wish to expose to unit testing. Having unit tests
reach too deeply in the code makes your test suite fragile. Instead,
use unit tests to exercise the code and verify external behavior while
letting the assertions verify internal consistency after each operation.

I have used Eiffel, have used design-by-contract principles in other
languages, and have followed the process with home grown macros for
longer than DBC has been called such. It is a useful tool, but DBC is
not magic and does not make the need for testing go away.

>
> Now come on and don't tell me: "We always used JUnit, most people do,
> why do you little inexperienced programer think you have a better
> idea than people like Gamma or Fowler?"
>
> I am not satisfied with the JUnit and TDD "paradigma". They are
> originated because of a *poverty* in Java programing language. If
> Java would support proper Design by Contract and a compiler for that
> than no one would bother with JUnit and TDD.
>
